channel.title: KenSmith tweets
channel.description: A feed of recent tweets from KenSmith.

item.description:
“Where suffrage is not universal. . .”

Exceptive: a system that doesn’t follow it own rules, that makes an exception, as in the right to vote. https://t.co/h4rlIIF35u
item.source:markdown:
“Where suffrage is not universal. . .”

item.description:
Brandi Carlile was so gently careful of what Joni Mitchell might want a little help with, moment by moment…

And that bubbling laughter from J. M. at the end…

https://t.co/r5G3h687Ws

item.description: A long thread following the Indiana Statehouse committee meeting today leading to approval of the Senate anti-abortion bill, which now goes before the full chamber. https://t.co/3VaflvqYUA
item.source:markdown: A long thread following the Indiana Statehouse committee meeting today leading to approval of the Senate anti-abortion bill, which now goes before the full chamber. https://t.co/3VaflvqYUA

item.description: @alastairmci He begins the essay by noting that powerful people in both near and faraway places are happy to define Czechoslovakian people’s lives for them. But the whole essay is about the authority we can all claim over the meaning of our lives, if we trust our judgment and if we dare.
item.source:markdown: @alastairmci He begins the essay by noting that powerful people in both near and faraway places are happy to define Czechoslovakian people’s lives for them. But the whole essay is about the authority we can all claim over the meaning of our lives, if we trust our judgment and if we dare.

item.description:
Yesterday in the Indiana Statehouse, a South Bend news station had wrapped up the early evening TV report. Very loud chanting was continuing across the way. I asked the reporter if he'd like a quotation about it all from a South Bend resident. The reporter wasn't much interested.

He asked, "Who are you?" in the tone that suggests the answer is "a nobody." "We have everything we need," he said, noting the day's report was about senators, not citizens. I suggested that he photograph my quote for later, and he did. A lukewarm experience for one and all.
item.source:markdown:
Yesterday in the Indiana Statehouse, a South Bend news station had wrapped up the early evening TV report. Very loud chanting was continuing across the way. I asked the reporter if he'd like a quotation about it all from a South Bend resident. The reporter wasn't much interested.
He asked, "Who are you?" in the tone that suggests the answer is "a nobody." "We have everything we need," he said, noting the day's report was about senators, not citizens. I suggested that he photograph my quote for later, and he did. A lukewarm experience for one and all.

item.description: @bellagloriashi1 I didn't see the rifle yesterday, Monday, but the same folks in green fatigues were up in those low towers yesterday (Monday) just west of the Statehouse.

item.description:
Sixty paces from an entrance to the Indiana Statehouse, the State Police SWAT team is on alert right now with rifle, scope for distance, tripod for accuracy. So, it’s serious.

It’s serious. https://t.co/jp4SgSOJoQ

By which I mean precautions are being taken.
item.source:markdown:
Sixty paces from an entrance to the Indiana Statehouse, the State Police SWAT team is on alert right now with rifle, scope for distance, tripod for accuracy. So, it’s serious.
It’s serious. https://t.co/jp4SgSOJoQ
By which I mean precautions are being taken.

item.description: Liz Cheney's bridge too far. https://t.co/PeNbOIe8Uu
item.source:markdown: Liz Cheney's bridge too far. https://t.co/PeNbOIe8Uu

item.description:
In World War II history, "a bridge too far" refers to a military plan of attack that was too ambitious. Troops captured a string of bridges but the fifth and final bridge in the plan turned out to be "a bridge too far," meaning "something in a plan that was too difficult."

The soldiers charged with the duty of carrying out that plan struggled mightily, sacrificed hugely, but their sacrifices were not enough for the last goal to be achieved. Back then, the phrase "a bridge too far" acknowledged these things.

Some of the Jan. 6 attackers on the Capitol, sent home by Trump with his expression of love that afternoon, probably think that they were like the W. W. II soldiers involved in a plan of attack that was too difficult, too far, for that moment in history. The old meaning.

Language changes, of course. Nowadays we still hear of something being "a bridge too far" but it tends to refer to ethics. "Yes, I'll withhold data about our product but I won't lie directly to a customer's face. That would be a bridge too far."

So, two very different meanings, and they are at risk of blurring. One is about superhuman sacrifice, and the other is about what bad thing one will or will not do for the sake of power or wealth.

One way to look at the Republican Party is to ask when, if ever, will they draw the line, saying: Ethically, this goes too far. "Yes, we will look the other way during our own and Trump's excesses," they seem to say. Just a handful now say the Jan. 6 coup was a bridge too far.

It's good that some testified in the TV hearings. For them, something about the coup was, ethically, a bridge too far. (If it had succeeded, well, who knows.) But, ethically, bridge after bridge in Trump's time should have been, for them, a bridge too far. But wasn't.

Republicans speaking up now, finally, testifying finally, carried out the second meaning, the ignoble meaning. This is why Jeffrey C. Isaac gives Liz Cheney only two cheers in this essay about her work on the Jan. 6 panel. https://t.co/OlwqVvMLnr
item.source:markdown:
In World War II history, "a bridge too far" refers to a military plan of attack that was too ambitious. Troops captured a string of bridges but the fifth and final bridge in the plan turned out to be "a bridge too far," meaning "something in a plan that was too difficult."
The soldiers charged with the duty of carrying out that plan struggled mightily, sacrificed hugely, but their sacrifices were not enough for the last goal to be achieved. Back then, the phrase "a bridge too far" acknowledged these things.
Some of the Jan. 6 attackers on the Capitol, sent home by Trump with his expression of love that afternoon, probably think that they were like the W. W. II soldiers involved in a plan of attack that was too difficult, too far, for that moment in history. The old meaning.
Language changes, of course. Nowadays we still hear of something being "a bridge too far" but it tends to refer to ethics. "Yes, I'll withhold data about our product but I won't lie directly to a customer's face. That would be a bridge too far."
So, two very different meanings, and they are at risk of blurring. One is about superhuman sacrifice, and the other is about what bad thing one will or will not do for the sake of power or wealth.
One way to look at the Republican Party is to ask when, if ever, will they draw the line, saying: Ethically, this goes too far. "Yes, we will look the other way during our own and Trump's excesses," they seem to say. Just a handful now say the Jan. 6 coup was a bridge too far.
It's good that some testified in the TV hearings. For them, something about the coup was, ethically, a bridge too far. (If it had succeeded, well, who knows.) But, ethically, bridge after bridge in Trump's time should have been, for them, a bridge too far. But wasn't.
Republicans speaking up now, finally, testifying finally, carried out the second meaning, the ignoble meaning. This is why Jeffrey C. Isaac gives Liz Cheney only two cheers in this essay about her work on the Jan. 6 panel. https://t.co/OlwqVvMLnr

item.description: A director once filmed Daryl Hannah from behind in the most emotional moment of a scene. Another filmed Keanu Reeves from the far end of a long hallway at a similar moment. Maybe those directors didn't trust the actors to show a closer camera a credible performance.
item.source:markdown: A director once filmed Daryl Hannah from behind in the most emotional moment of a scene. Another filmed Keanu Reeves from the far end of a long hallway at a similar moment. Maybe those directors didn't trust the actors to show a closer camera a credible performance.

item.description: How innovative corporations shoot themselves in the foot, drive away smart collaborators, constrict their best creations, and help people learn to hate them. https://t.co/xkqlNKtaWb
item.source:markdown: How innovative corporations shoot themselves in the foot, drive away smart collaborators, constrict their best creations, and help people learn to hate them. https://t.co/xkqlNKtaWb

item.description:
Recognizing how language plays its long game, Judge John @Hodgman goes full Humpty Dumpty on the meaning of brunch.

"‘When I use a word,’ Humpty Dumpty said in rather a scornful tone, ‘it means just what I choose it to mean–neither more nor less.’"

https://t.co/ZSPvVisCrD
item.source:markdown:
Recognizing how language plays its long game, Judge John @Hodgman goes full Humpty Dumpty on the meaning of brunch.
"‘When I use a word,’ Humpty Dumpty said in rather a scornful tone, ‘it means just what I choose it to mean–neither more nor less.’"
https://t.co/ZSPvVisCrD

item.description: When activists speak, they use words that reflect their world view. Politicos and bureaucrats always try to take over and redefine the key terms asserted by others. I lost the source, but a few days ago I read a comment making that point.
item.source:markdown: When activists speak, they use words that reflect their world view. Politicos and bureaucrats always try to take over and redefine the key terms asserted by others. I lost the source, but a few days ago I read a comment making that point.

item.description: Mikhail Bakhtin was interested in the ways the logics and power plays of a society's various discourses can be made easier to see.
item.source:markdown: Mikhail Bakhtin was interested in the ways the logics and power plays of a society's various discourses can be made easier to see.

item.description: T F To learn an academic discipline is to seal yourself within its thick, windowless walls.
item.source:markdown: T F To learn an academic discipline is to seal yourself within its thick, windowless walls.

item.description: Clues to the various ways the powerful speak differently when they know we can hear them, act differently when we know they can see them?
item.source:markdown: Clues to the various ways the powerful speak differently when they know we can hear them, act differently when we know they can see them?
